title: HIV: Advocating for Yourself

content: Living with HIV requires adjustments, including the need to adapt to the realities of your situation. One example is managing your medical care.  Although details differ from person to person, here are some aspects we all face.

First, finding the right fit with a doctor is important. This is even more true when you test positive for HIV. Much of living with HIV involves monitoring the progression (and suppression) of your disease. For most, there’s a learning curve. Walking into this process right after receiving a positive diagnosis can feel overwhelming and frightening.
My initial experience seeing a doctor after testing positive was a blessing in disguise , as it taught me the importance of advocating for myself.

After testing positive for HIV, I was told to see an infectious disease specialist. I was afraid and concerned and in a delicate state of mind. I didn’t ask many questions, but I was aware of what the doctor said. I listened closely to the information I was receiving. The appointment had almost finished, when she started speaking out loud to herself about what tests to order. (I remember thinking she wasn’t the warmest individual I’d encountered.) Still, I was going along with everything until she mumbled, “ We’ll also have to possibly schedule a spinal tap.” I asked why that was necessary. Without even looking up from the chart, she said, "Because we have to make sure the HIV hasn’t spread to your brain."

content: Then I was even more terrified and worried than I was before the appointment.

But that experience helped me become more forthright about having the right fit with my doctors. Fortunately, there were several other specialists available, and I was paired with another one. Not only were they compassionate and kind, but they were also extremely knowledgeable and took the time to explain everything to me in great detail. Most importantly, they made sure to explain the importance of ME being in the driver’s seat when it came to my HIV care. They were patient and created space for me to ask questions and take notes. So I knew what the terminology meant.

content: That experience taught me a valuable lesson about how important it is to speak up for myself and insist on what I want and need.

My journey to find the right doctor was more valuable than I realized at the time. It empowered me to be in the driver's seat when it comes to all things related to my medical care – particularly with HIV.

content: How we handle and manage our medical care is of the utmost importance. But it’s common to not know what questions to ask, or what to be on the lookout for, especially if you’re walking into it blindly.

Understanding how viral load, CD4 count, liver and kidney functions, and so many other things factor into monitoring your HIV care are part of the “living with HIV toolkit” each person has to learn. Developing this knowledge is even more valuable when it comes to figuring out the best treatment regimen. Although health care providers and specialists know about medicines and their effectiveness, it’s a joint venture we must take WITH our doctors to make sure we receive the best treatment possible.

There are other examples of what it means to advocate for ourselves and others living with HIV. For me, it was becoming more active in HIV/AIDS outreach and prevention efforts through my artistic endeavors.

Two years into living with HIV, with the support of two other Black gay men living with HIV, I founded an arts, outreach, and education organization, Brave Soul Collective. It was the best way I knew to use my experiences to heal, grow, and become more confident in who I am as a person living with HIV.

Embarking on that journey is one of the best decisions I’ve made. It helps strengthen my journey. Others have been able to learn, connect, and be empowered through this community, and through the artistic works I’ve produced through Brave Soul Collective in the last 18 years. I never sought to be an advocate, but I now realize that’s exactly what I was doing without even realizing it.

content: Advocating for yourself and others is a personal choice, related to your level of comfort. The more we grow and learn in our walks as people living with HIV, there are wonderful opportunities to share information and help someone else. We can help them be empowered and develop skills to take better care of themselves.
Advocacy has the power to encourage others to live, thrive, and perhaps choose to be more vocal and visible.
